messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:40): so unless something unforeseen happens I'm going to Maastricht after all
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:49): annevk: how long is the meeting? I thought it would be over by now.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:50): it's tomorrow midday
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:50): I'm just going for hybi
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:56): annevk: "fun"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): so in the meta charset sniffing "UTF-16" is special-cased
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:57): we'll see
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): does that really mean "UTF-16" only or also BE, LE and 32?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:57): hopefully talking F2F will help clarify a few things
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:57): UTF-32 is irrelevant
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:58): iirc it just means UTF-16 case-insensitive
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): ok. how about the other cases in the spec where the charset of a URL is checked for "UTF-16", does that mean BE and LE, too?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): (my guess is yes)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:59): oh sorry
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:59): it says "a UTF-16 encoding"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:59): I guess that means all of them
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:00): aliases, too?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:00): it seems to me Safari doesn't do aliases
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:01): UTF-16 is such a bad idea :-(
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:01): must have seemed great at the time
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:01): aliases too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:01): in fact, lots of the encoding stuff are pretty bad ideas
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): one day i'll sort it out
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): and ICU can be obsoleted
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): I made quite a bit of progress with encoding detection
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:02): annevk: it's good to have goals
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): and encodings to be supported by popular user agents
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:03): what there's yet to do is defining for each encoding how it maps to Unicode
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:03): (and possibly how it maps back)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:03): annevk: doesn't ftp.unicode.org already do that except for Microsoft deltas?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:03): in more detail than encodings are defined today (e.g. precise error handling for UTF-8) and more compatible (lots of ASIAN encodings support more than the standards indicate)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:05): Woohoo. at least this iso-10646 thing isn't my mistake but a spec bug :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:26): Philip`: do you happen to have something that you could grep for pages that say iso-10646 in meta and don't have an HTTP-level charset?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:27): I'd like to know if those pages work better as UTF-8 or as Windows-1252
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:27): or UTF-8 vs. chardet + default
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:30): Philip`: it would be great to have similar data for UTF-16BE, UTF-16LE, UTF-32, UTF-32BE and UTF-32LE
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets-2.html#charset-iso-10646-1

58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (14:33): Ericsson seems to be playing around with implementing <device> in WebKit: https://labs.ericsson.com/blog/beyond-html5-implementing-device-and-stream-management-webkit
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:33): Philip`: thanks! (looks like a rare value, thankfully)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:33): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Also http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets.html#charset-iso-10646 from a smaller but possibly more reliable set of pages
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): doesn't entirely trust his data analysis, particularly for non-ASCII-compatible encodings
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:39): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354, pretty cool
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:39): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354, though not sure why they use video_player rather than media

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:59): Looks like it might be http://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/WebCore/loader/TextResourceDecoder.cpp?rev=64262#L344

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:00): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: OK. Do you have any opinion on the framing issue? Both technical and whether it is worth discussing in the "four week" timescale?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:00): Philip`: interesting. thanks. that doesn't match my black-box testing, though
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:01): (I wonder if we should be saying "message" instead of "frame")
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:01): (or I misinterpret what "Default" means in Safari's menu)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:01): does Default in Safari mean "what page said" or "user's default"?

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:01): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I think length-delimited text frames would be slightly technically superior to sentinel-delimited, but I don't care very much either way

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:02): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I think it's essential for text and binary to be clearly distinguished, and I think using presence/absence of a MIME type or whether the MIME type starts with text/ are very poor ways to signal text vs binary
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:03): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: if we want to change text frames to be length-delimited, it probably needs to happen sooner rather than later
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:03): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: OK, that mirrors my thoughts rather well. SO I am a little more confident that I am not toally off base :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:04): I wonder if no one is discussing the handshake issue because they don't feel confident, or simply because the conversation has been led astray
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:05): Philip`: blame points to encoding, not decoding: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=21635
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:06): wonders what proportion of Web users globally is behind a proxy
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:22): non-UTF-8 encodings lead to unhappiness
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:22): yeah
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:23): can't believe this Greg Wilkins is pushing for non-UTF-8 support in WebSocket
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:23): I often get the feeling with him he's just pushing for features
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:23): features and complexity
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:24): annevk: I trust Hixie is good at saying "no" in that case
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:25): annevk: what's the rationale for non-UTF-8?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:26): Hixie: fwiw, when <acronym> is obsoleted, it would be logical to zap <strong>, <em>, <kbd>, <samp> and <cite>, too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:27): UTF-16 was there and "potential future encodings"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:27): (maybe not practical for validator user-friendliness but consistent with the removal of <acronym>)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:27): annevk: that's so sad
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:29): If we ever run out of UTF-8, it's more likely to start allowing 6-byte sequences than to come up with something new
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:43): it in fact allowed those once

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:28): The odd behaviour in WebKit reproduces though

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:29): (but did in WebKit, where I think it is not a race condition, just mildly crazy)
